content: The "Track It to Prevent It Act" is the short title of this Act, with a table of contents provided. The "Track It to Prevent It Act" includes provisions for improved climate assessments, inclusion of various types of reprimands, service-wide 360 assessments, health welfare inspections, review of security at military installations, and the role of the Office of Diversity Management and Equal Opportunity in sexual harassment cases. Authorization of appropriations is also included. SEC. 2. FINDINGS. Congress finds that in fiscal year 2012, there were 3,374 reported sexual assault cases in the Armed Forces, a 6% increase from the previous year. Additionally, approximately 26,000 members made anonymous reports of sexual assault, a significant rise from the previous year. In fiscal year 2012, 6.1% of female members experienced unwanted sexual contact, with 77% reporting such incidents. In fiscal year 2012, there was a substantial increase in reported sexual assault cases in the Armed Forces. 6.1% of female members experienced unwanted sexual contact, with 77% also facing sexual harassment. Additionally, 1.2% of male members experienced unwanted sexual contact, with 52% also experiencing sexual harassment. In fiscal year 2012, 62% of members who experienced unwanted sexual contact perceived some form of retaliation. Commanders must comply with climate assessments to create a safe environment. Trends in bad behavior and reoccurring actions are concerning. In fiscal year 2012, 62% of members who experienced unwanted sexual contact also perceived some form of social, administrative, or professional retaliation. Climate assessments are required by law for commanders to create a safe environment. Trends in bad behavior like sexual harassment and assault must be identified earlier through improved performance assessments and reporting. Trends in bad behavior like sexual harassment and assault must be identified earlier through improved performance assessments and reporting. Members often do not report incidents due to fear of repercussions on their military career and lack of confidence in action being taken. Members often do not report sexual harassment and assault incidents in the military because they fear nothing will be done about it and worry about negative impacts on their career. Commanders' tolerance or ignorance of such misconduct perpetuates this culture. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "sexual harassment" is defined in Department of Defense Directive 1350.2, and "sexual assault" refers to offenses described in section 920 of title 10, United States Code. The Secretary of Defense must ensure that command climate assessment results are shared with relevant commanders and higher levels of command. Each military department must include a designated form in performance evaluations for senior commanders to indicate if required climate assessments have been conducted. Failure to conduct assessments will have consequences. The Department of Defense requires senior commanders to indicate if climate assessments have been conducted in performance evaluations. Failure to conduct assessments will impact the commander's promotion prospects. The Inspector General will oversee a tracking system. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will develop a tracking system to monitor commanders' compliance with conducting climate assessments. Unit commanders will work with the Inspector General to gather assessments and create compliance reports. Failure to conduct assessments will be noted in a commander's performance evaluation and may affect their chances of promotion. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will develop a tracking system to monitor commanders' compliance with conducting climate assessments. Unit commanders, in collaboration with the Inspector General, will compile assessments and create compliance reports detailing concerns, leadership perception, and strategic plans for addressing issues. SEC. 5. INCLUSION OF LETTER OF REPRIMANDS, NONPUNITIVE LETTER OF REPRIMANDS AND COUNSELING STATEMENTS. The Secretary of Defense mandates commanders to include reprimands, actions, and counseling related to sexual harassment or assault in performance evaluations to increase visibility, identify trends, discipline bad behavior, and prevent transfer of offenders. Additionally, there is a provision for service-wide 360 assessments. The Secretary of each military department is required to develop an assessment program based on the 360-degree approach. The Secretary of Defense must report to Congress on the feasibility of including this approach in performance evaluation reports. Individual counseling is also mandated as part of the program. The Secretary of Defense must report to Congress within 90 days on the feasibility of including the 360-degree approach in performance evaluations. Individual counseling is required as part of the evaluation process. SEC. 7. HEALTH WELFARE INSPECTIONS. The Secretary of each military department conducts monthly health welfare inspections to ensure security, military readiness, and discipline. Results are provided to commanders. SEC. 8. REVIEW OF SECURITY OF MILITARY INSTALLATIONS, INCLUDING BARRACKS AND MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENCES. The Secretary of Defense will review security measures on military installations, focusing on barracks and multi-family residences to ensure the safety of Armed Forces members and their dependents. This includes identifying security gaps and evaluating the use of 24-hour electronic monitoring or security personnel. The Secretary of Defense will review security measures on military installations, focusing on identifying security gaps and evaluating the feasibility of 24-hour electronic monitoring or security personnel at all entry points into barracks and multi-family residences. A report containing the study results and cost estimates must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Defense will assess security gaps at military installations, including entry points into barracks and multi-family residences. A report with cost estimates to address these gaps and provide 24-hour security monitoring must be submitted to Congress within 90 days. SEC. 9. REVIEW OF THE OFFICE OF DIVERSITY MANAGEMENT AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY ROLE IN SEXUAL HARASSMENT CASES. The Secretary of Defense will review the Office of Diversity Management and Equal Opportunity to identify resource gaps, assess its role in sexual harassment cases, and evaluate its collaboration with the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided to the Secretary of Defense for fiscal year 2014 to carry out the Act.
